text:
I'm starting working with a new client this week and they want to take an 'interview' approach to content creation. i.e. they come up with a general idea, I do a bit of research, we do an interview and then I go away and write something up based on the interview and my notes.

*Having never worked this way before, what advice do those that have done, have for making it work successfully?*

E.g. do you try and stick to the questions that your research suggests need answering, or go a bit more free-form and work it out afterwards.

And if you know that most pages ranking for the keyterms are a lot longer than you're planning/have scoped (we've agreed up to 1500 words, but commonly ~4000 words is the norm for the keywords we're looking at for the first piece) would you split things out into 3 part series or suggest that the word count means it requires a longer piece and charge more?

Any advice/guidance gratefully received :slightly_smiling_face:

Any advice/guidance gratefully received

text:
Any tips on how to convince a CMO that their B2B marketing team should shift from a publication-style content strategy to library-style?

<https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/|https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/>

Specifically looking for a way to estimate the impact of a library-style strategy, e.g., “we could increase leads/organic search traffic by X%.”

attachments.title: Your Blog Is Not a Publication - Animalz
attachments.text: The best content strategy is the one that prioritizes quality and depth, not volume and breadth. Think like a library, and not a publication.
attachments.fallback: Animalz: Your Blog Is Not a Publication - Animalz

elements.text: Any tips on how to convince a CMO that their B2B marketing team should shift from a publication-style content strategy to library-style?
https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/
Specifically looking for a way to estimate the impact of a library-style strategy, e.g., “we could increase leads/organic search traffic by X%.”

text:
"What’s happening here is that as you travel higher up inside an organization the decisions get more important, but attention spans get shorter and so the information gets more compressed. The CEO trusts that the VP has pre-vetted and analyzed the situation - what they expect is a condensed view of the relevant information to make a decision.

This compression is important. And if you want to be effective at the executive layer you need to compress and package your ideas well. There’s three things to focus on, you need to be *concise, credible & compelling."*


<https://seomba.substack.com/p/presenting-to-the-ceo-in-5-slides>

attachments.title: Presenting to the CEO in 5 slides
attachments.text: How to make your ideas concise, credible & compelling
attachments.fallback: Presenting to the CEO in 5 slides

elements.text:

This compression is important. And if you want to be effective at the executive layer you need to compress and package your ideas well. There’s three things to focus on, you need to be
concise, credible & compelling."

text: For a KPI-oriented exec, I'd frame it around the "spike of hope, flatline of nope" concept: <https://ahrefs.com/blog/why-seo-is-important/>

text: So, say your corporate blog has 1,000 people that will read a new piece of thought-leadershipy content (super unlikely, but hey).  If you want 30K visitors per month, you need to publish an article every day.

elements.text: So, say your corporate blog has 1,000 people that will read a new piece of thought-leadershipy content (super unlikely, but hey).  If you want 30K visitors per month, you need to publish an article every day.

text: And that traffic completely stops as soon as you turn off the content faucet

elements.text: And that traffic completely stops as soon as you turn off the content faucet

text: But if you put that kind of effort into organic traffic/library articles, over say, six months, you'd produce 180 articles.  Assuming the average one of articles brought even a modest 300 visitors per month, that's 54K visitors per month.  And that faucet doesn't turn off -- it keeps going for years after you stop producing content.

elements.text: But if you put that kind of effort into organic traffic/library articles, over say, six months, you'd produce 180 articles.  Assuming the average one of articles brought even a modest 300 visitors per month, that's 54K visitors per month.  And that faucet doesn't turn off -- it keeps going for years after you stop producing content.

text: (I'd replace my hand-wavy assumptions with actual traffic from articles on the site, and lay out the case with those numbers, assuming you have them)

elements.text: (I'd replace my hand-wavy assumptions with actual traffic from articles on the site, and lay out the case with those numbers, assuming you have them)

text:
This may be slightly different than what you're doing, but I just finished an article interviewing an SME. We had a very broad, general idea of the final outcome.

It was "create a series featuring professionals in [THIS] industry"

So, I created a strategy document listing the goals, target audience of the final article, target job positions of the reader, interview topic ideas, potential questions, and outcomes.

I came up with a list of questions that were both personal to the individual and also relevant to the industry and indirectly related to the SaaS product the 'series' company offers.

Then for the interview itself, I emailed him ahead of time with a brief generalized overview of what I would ask about. In the interview, I started with simple intro questions, then asked job and industry-related questions. I then just followed his lead on some answers he gave.

Once I got some info from those answers, I would guide it back to my other potential questions. In about 30 minutes, we got through about 10-12 questions.

I recorded the interview, transcribed it, then did lots of editing to create relevant headers as questions.

Additionally, I researched multiple relevant industry-related statistics to help add some 'meat' to the article. Then, I added screenshots of the data and statistics.

I created a Table of Contents and also added a Summary of bullet points at the beginning of the article.

At the end, I added a list of all the Links in the article (like a citations list, but just the titles and links)

Excluding the Table of Contents and the Link titles at the end, the final article was 2,008 words.

And now, I'm going to write a blog post about all this. haha.

elements.text:
This may be slightly different than what you're doing, but I just finished an article interviewing an SME. We had a very broad, general idea of the final outcome.

It was "create a series featuring professionals in [THIS] industry"

So, I created a strategy document listing the goals, target audience of the final article, target job positions of the reader, interview topic ideas, potential questions, and outcomes.

I came up with a list of questions that were both personal to the individual and also relevant to the industry and indirectly related to the SaaS product the 'series' company offers.

Then for the interview itself, I emailed him ahead of time with a brief generalized overview of what I would ask about. In the interview, I started with simple intro questions, then asked job and industry-related questions. I then just followed his lead on some answers he gave.

Once I got some info from those answers, I would guide it back to my other potential questions. In about 30 minutes, we got through about 10-12 questions.

I recorded the interview, transcribed it, then did lots of editing to create relevant headers as questions.

Additionally, I researched multiple relevant industry-related statistics to help add some 'meat' to the article. Then, I added screenshots of the data and statistics.

I created a Table of Contents and also added a Summary of bullet points at the beginning of the article.

At the end, I added a list of all the Links in the article (like a citations list, but just the titles and links)

Excluding the Table of Contents and the Link titles at the end, the final article was 2,008 words.

And now, I'm going to write a blog post about all this. haha.

text:
Also, is it possible the CMO is getting hung up on the _breaking news_ idea, and is worried you won’t seem relevant if you don’t have some kind of publication-style thing? A solution to that can be having _both_ a blog _and_ a library. New pieces (and updates) get posted to the blog when they happen, together with other corporate stuff. Substantive content stays in the library.

Another overlooked part of the library, by the way, is that a library is _much_ more helpful internally. For example, you can point sales reps there and even existing customers. Harder to do / use with something that’s organized as a newspaper.

And to <@UJG9WTEKG> and <@U017XD7H4P7>’s point, you’re potentially wasting lots of money and time if you don’t try to get your older articles updated. The biggest effort is creating, incremental updates are fast, very effective for increasing traffic, and relatively easy.

text: Does anyone have office hours scheduled for anyone at the company to come with questions or help (but not requests) on all things content marketing?

elements.text: Does anyone have office hours scheduled for anyone at the company to come with questions or help (but not requests) on all things content marketing?

text:
I've done this before but had a hard time getting folks to show up! I think there are ways it can work, but two improvements from my experience I'd recommend:
• give folks clear examples of things this would be valuable for so they can understand why they should attend
• if someone slacks you or asks a question that would make sense for office hours, instead of answering on the spot tell that person to come to office hours to build that habit and remind folks it exists as an option!

elements.text: I've done this before but had a hard time getting folks to show up! I think there are ways it can work, but two improvements from my experience I'd recommend:
give folks clear examples of things this would be valuable for so they can understand why they should attend

if someone slacks you or asks a question that would make sense for office hours, instead of answering on the spot tell that person to come to office hours to build that habit and remind folks it exists as an option!

text: A different team at our company (our inclusion and diversity council) has also done office hours before where they have a specific theme to help jog folks brains for things they could use office hours to discuss

elements.text: A different team at our company (our inclusion and diversity council) has also done office hours before where they have a specific theme to help jog folks brains for things they could use office hours to discuss

text:
Ooh - interesting. That sounds close to the plan that I have in mind. The only difference being that we've already said that the piece shouldn't be longer than 1500 words. I'm not sure whether I say

a) it needs to be longer and I'm going to need to charge you more,

or b) there's lots of interesting angles we can take here, let's break it down into smaller pieces

The issue with the latter is that we only have a 3-month (3 post) agreement, and each of them is supposed to be on a different topic :thinking_face:

text: Loving this concept. How well does it translate to B2C/DTC e-commerce?

elements.text: Loving this concept. How well does it translate to B2C/DTC e-commerce?

text:
Thanks so much for all your input!!

<@U013WCZ5GSV> - I think where our team is getting hung up is on content services vs content marketing. The primary motivation (even if we say it’s lead gen) is serving internal content requests, which tend to be publication-style. What I’d like to propose is that we still support some degree of content services requests, but that we also develop a content strategy and put effort behind library/hub pieces. I think SEO opportunity is a huge piece of this, too, like <@UJG9WTEKG> mentioned.
